TEXT: CARDINAL . NORP The applicant , PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and currently lives in GPE . He is represented before the Court by Mr Bo Johansson , a lawyer practising in GPE .
CARDINAL . The NORP Government ( “ the Government ” ) are represented by their Agent , PERSON , of ORG .
CARDINAL . The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

CARDINAL . According to the applicant , he entered GPE on DATE . However , the NORP authorities did not become aware of his existence until DATE , when the police happened to ask him for his personal documents . As he was residing illegally in the country , the police prepared for his immediate expulsion . The following day the applicant applied for asylum , a residence permit and a work permit .
CARDINAL . ORG ( Migrationsverket ) held an initial short interview with the applicant on DATE , and a more extensive CARDINAL on DATE .

CARDINAL . During the first interview the applicant stated that he grew up in the town of PERSON , but moved to GPE in DATE , after he had finished high school . His oldest brother lived in GPE and was not allowed to return to GPE . The applicant was arrested by the police and sometimes subjected to torture .

CARDINAL . During the second interview the applicant , represented by counsel , explained , among other things , that his eldest brother moved to GPE in DATE to look for work and he married an NORP woman there . Since DATE the NORP authorities suspected that the brother belonged to a terrorist organisation and constituted a danger vis - à - vis GPE . The last time the brother visited GPE was in CARDINAL . Due to these suspicions , several times the applicant had been detained for DATE , during which time he was interrogated about his brother ’s whereabouts , beaten and tortured . The first time this happened was in DATE . He could not specify how many times he had been interrogated . He lived in PERSON until DATE . He lived in GPE from DATE until DATE and subsequently moved to GPE where he lived until DATE . Thereafter , he moved to PERSON , but returned to GPE CARDINAL and lived there until he left the country . Every time he was in PERSON to visit his mother he was taken to the police station for interrogation . This also happened in GPE , the last time being at DATE . He showed marks on his head and arm which allegedly were from the torture carried out in DATE . He stated that those were the only physical injuries he had suffered .

CARDINAL . Neither he , nor anyone else in his family had been politically active . His brother was not politically active in GPE and the applicant did not believe that his brother was active in GPE either since “ he was not that kind of person , who was politically active ” . All the applicant ’s problems were caused by the fact that his brother moved to GPE and was suspected of NORP terrorist activities .

CARDINAL . The applicant had not been granted a passport , but had managed to arrange for CARDINAL via contacts . Since he arrived in GPE he had stayed with his sister , helping out with her gravely handicapped daughter , born in DATE .

CARDINAL . In a letter of CARDINAL DATE to ORG , the applicant ’s counsel stated that TIME the second interview were correctly recorded , but added that the applicant had also had a difficult social situation in his home country , including been subjected to social repression . Furthermore , the applicant suffered from serious psychological problems , such as nightmares , anxiety , depression and insomnia .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG refused to grant the applicant asylum . It found that the fact that the applicant had waited DATE before he applied for asylum indicated that he did not consider himself to be in strong need of protection . Moreover , it found the veracity of the applicant ’s story questionable , notably since he had not himself been politically active and had not been able to submit the name of the organisation to which the NORP authorities accused the applicant ’s brother of belonging . There was no reason to believe that the applicant was of any particular interest to the NORP authorities .

CARDINAL . NORP The applicant appealed against the decision to ORG ( Utlänningsnämnden ) , before which he repeated that he had been persecuted because the NORP authorities considered that his brother was a terrorist and that consequently , the applicant had been arrested CARDINAL times , during which he was tortured . His injuries were still visible although DATE had passed since the last time he had been ill - treated . The applicant also invoked bad health and a strong family attachment between him and his niece . He explained that the reason why he had not submitted his asylum application upon entry into GPE was that he feared being returned to GPE immediately .

CARDINAL . In a submission of CARDINAL DATE the applicant ’s counsel added that the applicant had been prohibited from leaving GPE and that according to new information from the applicant there was now a judgment against him for violating a travel ban . Thus , if he returned to GPE he would be arrested , tortured and risk being killed . Counsel thus requested an extension to submit the said judgment . Subsequently , at DATE , the applicant submitted fax copies of CARDINAL documents in LANGUAGE ( appendix nos . I , II , and III ) to ORG . CARDINAL of them was allegedly the said judgment .

CARDINAL . On DATE , at a court hearing regarding reconsideration of a detention order against the applicant , a translator was present , whom counsel asked about the CARDINAL documents , notably whether CARDINAL of them was a judgment concerning a travel ban . The translator replied in the negative , but stated that CARDINAL document concerned a judgment imposing a DATE prison sentence on the applicant for membership of a forbidden organisation and another document was a summons to a court hearing .

CARDINAL . In a letter of CARDINAL DATE to ORG , counsel invoked the judgment as proof of the ill - treatment to which the applicant had been subjected and the risks he would face upon return to GPE .

CARDINAL . ORG informed the applicant and his counsel that the documents , including the alleged judgement , would not be formally translated or checked for authenticity since they had been transmitted only as fax copies as opposed to originals . It further noted that the applicant had not provided a satisfactory explanation as to why and how he had been sentenced as alleged or why he had not previously mentioned or submitted the judgment . In reply , on DATE counsel maintained that the applicant ’s relatives had tried in vain to obtain an original of the judgment , according to which the applicant had been accused of being politically active in an illegal organisation called CARDINAL . However , the court refused to release the judgment in the applicant ’s absence and the reason why the judgment had not been mentioned before was that it had been passed in the applicant ’s absence on DATE after the court had asserted that the applicant was abroad .

CARDINAL . On DATE , finding that none of the circumstances invoked by the applicant were strong enough to give him asylum status or to grant him a residence permit , ORG upheld ORG decision . More specifically as to the alleged strong family attachment between the applicant and his niece , ORG pointed out that the applicant had never lived with his sister in GPE , before she was granted a permanent residence permit in GPE in DATE , nor had he applied for asylum or a residence permit with reference to his family link when he arrived in GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant submitted a so - called new application for a residence permit to ORG , adding that he had been active in the forbidden NORP organisation an - Nahdha and that ORG had not given sufficient weight to the judgment against him . He also referred to the human rights situation in GPE and emphasised that his attachment to his niece had become very strong , notably after his sister divorced her husband due to domestic violence .
CARDINAL . On DATE , again ORG rejected the applicant ’s application . As to the alleged judgment , referring to its previous finding , the ORG gave it little weight as evidence .

CARDINAL . On DATE , the applicant submitted a second so - called new application to ORG , enclosing a letter of DATE , repeated on DATE , by a NORP organisation called ORG ( PERSON ) , and a fax copy of a letter of DATE by ORG . The latter read as follows :
To whom it may concern ,
I , PERSON , Chairman of GPE ( ORG of GPE confirm that Mr. PERSON ( GPE ) is a sympathiser of our party . He came under threat because of his thoughts and political activities .
Given the present situation in GPE , we consider Mr. PERSON to be a grave risk of arrest , imprisonment and torture if returned to GPE .
Therefore , I would be very grateful if you positively consider his application for political asylum .
CARDINAL . NORP By decision of CARDINAL DATE , ORG refused anew to grant the applicant a residence permit .

CARDINAL . On DATE , immediately before the implementation of the deportation order , the applicant lodged the present application and requested that the ORG applied Rule CARDINAL of ORG . On DATE , following an indication given by the ORG , the applicant ’s deportation was stayed until further notice .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant submitted further information to the ORG and enclosed a translation of the aforementioned appendix no . II , which stated as follows :
Ministry of Justice
ORG in GPE
Ref . no . CARDINAL
To LOC ORG
Referring to LAW , you are requested to communicate to
PERSON ,
That he has been convicted in absentia by ORG in GPE by judgment of CARDINAL pursuant to LAW , and sentenced to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment for membership of an illegal party .
The Registrar ( unreadable signature )

CARDINAL . On DATE , ORG examining the applicant ’s case on its own initiative , in accordance with a temporary provision of LAW , found that the applicant could not be granted residence permits under the temporary wording of LAW , section CARDINAL b of LAW . Before it the applicant had submitted a summons for questioning of DATE , in LANGUAGE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant once again applied for a residence permit under the temporary provision of LAW . The application was rejected by ORG on DATE .

CARDINAL . Before the ORG the applicant alleged , inter alia , that he was introduced to PERSON through his older brother at DATE , and that his brother had to flee to GPE by the time the applicant got involved in the party . He worked for the party by distributing messages , mail and leaflets . He was regularly arrested for periods DATE and ill - treated . At some point there was a nationwide warrant against him and in DATE he was detained for DATE . In DATE he moved to the country side around GPE and had agricultural jobs . Thereafter , he was no longer politically active but he remained in contact with some of the NORP party members . At DATE he contemplated leaving the country but did not do so until DATE . Before the ORG , the applicant also submitted the original of the letter of DATE by ORG . It had been difficult to obtain the NORP documents . They were not acquired by the applicant but by his sister and brother - in - law living in GPE , with the assistance of ORG , and with the help of a lawyer hired by the applicant ’s mother . Thus , the documents were transmitted by fax . It was not possible to send the original by mail until later .

CARDINAL . Providing various examples , the Government pointed out that most of the applicant ’s statements before the ORG were new to them and not consistent with the information submitted previously before the NORP migration authorities .

CARDINAL . NORP Moreover , in DATE , the ORG requested ORG in GPE to provide certain information regarding the documents submitted by the applicant and allegedly issued by NORP authorities . Via an attorney in GPE , who submitted a report on DATE , the following was submitted among other things . Under NORP procedural law it was prohibited for any person ( irrespective of his or her occupation or authority ) , who was not a party to the lawsuit or who had not intervened during the legal case ( as an expert or a lawyer of CARDINAL of the parties to the legal matter ) to have access to the legal file . Hence , it was not possible to verify or disprove by this means , whether the invoked documents existed de facto . However , there were several irregularities in the documents invoked by the applicant . More importantly , as regards the CARDINAL documents invoked by the applicant before ORG , it was established that none of them was a judgment . Instead appendix I , II , and III were respectively a summons to a court hearing , an order of service and a certificate of service of a judgment . The CARDINAL latter documents contained references to a judgment against the applicant regarding membership of a forbidden organisation .

CARDINAL . A new Aliens Act ( SFS CARDINAL:CARDINAL ) , replacing the DATE LAW , entered into force on DATE . The Act established a new system for examining and determining applications for asylum and residence permits . While ORG continued to carry out the initial examination , an appeal against the ORG ’s decision was determined by CARDINAL of the CARDINAL new migration courts . ORG was the court of final instance . It examined appeals against the decisions of the migration courts , provided leave to appeal was granted . Upon the entry into force of LAW , ORG ceased to exist . ORG acted as the alien ’s opposing party in proceedings before the courts .

CARDINAL . The provisions mainly applied in the present case were to be found in the DATE LAW , now repealed . In accordance with the LAW , an alien staying in GPE for DATE had to , as a rule , have a residence permit ( chapter CARDINAL , section CARDINAL ) . A residence permit could be issued , inter alia , to an alien who , for humanitarian reasons , was to be allowed to settle in GPE ( chapter CARDINAL , section CARDINAL ) . Serious physical or mental illness could , in exceptional cases , constitute humanitarian reasons for the granting of a residence permit .

CARDINAL . An alien who was considered to be a refugee or otherwise in need of protection was , with certain exceptions , entitled to a residence permit in GPE ( chapter CARDINAL , section CARDINAL ) . The term “ refugee ” referred to an alien who was outside the country of his nationality owing to a well - founded fear of being persecuted for reasons of race , nationality , membership of a particular social group , or religious or political opinion , and who was unable or , owing to such fear , unwilling to avail himself of the protection of that country . This applied irrespective of whether such persecution was at the hands of the authorities of the country or whether those authorities could not be expected to offer protection against persecution by private individuals ( chapter CARDINAL , section CARDINAL ) . An “ alien otherwise in need of protection ” denoted , inter alia , a person who had left the country of his nationality because he had a well - founded fear of being sentenced to death or corporal punishment or of being subjected to torture or other inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment ( chapter CARDINAL , section CARDINAL , subsection CARDINAL ) . By making that a separate ground for granting a residence permit , the legislature had highlighted the importance of such considerations . The correspondence between national legislation and LAW had been emphasised as a result .

CARDINAL . In enforcing a decision on refusal of entry or expulsion , the risk of torture and other inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment was taken into account . In accordance with a special provision on impediments to enforcement , an alien could not be sent to a country where there were reasonable grounds for believing that he would be in danger of suffering capital or corporal punishment or of being subjected to torture or other inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment ( chapter CARDINAL , section CARDINAL ) . In addition , he could not , in principle , be sent to a country where he risked persecution ( chapter CARDINAL , section CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . Until DATE an alien who was to be refused entry or expelled in accordance with a decision that had gained legal force could be granted a residence permit if he filed a so - called “ new application ” with ORG based on circumstances which had not previously been examined in the case concerning refusal of entry or expulsion . A residence permit could then be granted if the alien was entitled to a residence permit under LAW , section CARDINAL , of the LAW or if it would be contrary to the requirements of humanity to enforce the refusal - of - entry or expulsion decision ( chapter CARDINAL , section CARDINAL b , in its wording before DATE ) .

CARDINAL . Amendments to chapter CARDINAL , section CARDINAL b , of the DATE LAW entered into force on DATE , whereby a new legal remedy of a temporary nature was introduced . The new procedure for obtaining a residence permit replaced the rules relating to new applications for a residence permit laid down in chapter CARDINAL , section CARDINAL b , in its previous wording . Furthermore , the amendments to the DATE Act introduced additional legal grounds for granting a residence permit to aliens against whom a final expulsion order had been made . The object of these temporary amendments was to grant residence permits to aliens who , inter alia , had been in GPE for a very long time or where there existed “ urgent humanitarian interests ” ( humanitärt angeläget ) . Special consideration was given to the situation of children . The temporary provisions remained in force until the new LAW entered into force on DATE . ORG continued , however , to examine applications which it had received before that date but had not yet determined .
C. Relevant background material
CARDINAL . ORG , GPE , Country Reports on ORG , DATE , stated , inter alia , of relevance to the present case :

“ ... The government continued to commit serious human rights abuses . There were significant limitations on ORG right to change their government . Members of the security forces tortured and physically abused prisoners and detainees . Security forces arbitrarily arrested and detained individuals . Authorities did not charge any police or security force official with abuse during DATE . Lengthy pre - trial and incommunicado detention remained a serious problem . The government infringed on ORG privacy rights , continued to impose severe restrictions on freedom of speech and of the press , and restricted freedom of assembly and association . The government remained intolerant of public criticism and used intimidation , criminal investigations , the court system , arbitrary arrests , residential restrictions , and travel controls ( including denial of passports ) , to discourage criticism by human rights and opposition activists . Corruption was a problem . ...
c. Torture and Other Cruel , Inhuman , or Degrading Treatment or Punishment

The law prohibits such practices ; however , according to human rights organizations , security forces tortured detainees to elicit confessions and discourage resistance . The forms of torture and other abuse included : sleep deprivation ; electric shock ; submersion of the head in water ; beatings with hands , sticks , and police batons ; suspension , sometimes manacled , from cell doors and rods resulting in loss of consciousness ; and cigarette burns . According to ORG ( AI ) , police and prison officials used sexual assault and threats of sexual assault against the wives of NORP prisoners to extract information , intimidate , and punish .

Charges of torture in specific cases were difficult to prove . Authorities often allegedly denied victims of torture access to medical care until evidence of abuse disappeared . The government maintained that it investigated all complaints of torture and mistreatment filed with the prosecutor ’s office and noted that alleged victims sometimes accused police of torture without filing a complaint , which is a prerequisite for an investigation .

According to defense attorneys and local and international human rights groups , police routinely refused to register complaints of torture . In addition , judges dismissed complaints without investigation and accepted as evidence confessions allegedly extracted through torture . The government has the ability to open an administrative investigation of allegations of torture or mistreatment of prisoners without a formal complaint ; however , in those cases the results have not been made public or available to the lawyers of affected prisoners .

Consistent with an effort to extract information or coerce confessions , reports of torture were more frequently associated with the initial phases of interrogation / investigation and pre - trial detention centers more than prisons . Human rights activists , citing prisoner accounts , identified facilities at ORG as the most common location for torture . Political prisoners , NORP , and persons detained on terrorism - related charges allegedly received harsher treatment than other prisoners and detainees . ...
Prison and ORG

Prison conditions ranged from spartan to poor and generally did not meet international standards . Although overcrowding and limited medical care posed a significant threat to prisoners’ health , new prison facilities at ORG and greater access to healthcare improved the situation .

According to human rights organizations , prison conditions in the country continued to fall short of minimum adequate standards . Hygiene was extremely poor , and prisoners rarely had access to showers and washing facilities . Sources reported that CARDINAL prisoners were typically confined to QUANTITY cell , and CARDINAL prisoners shared a QUANTITY cell . Most prisoners were forced to share beds or sleep on the floor . Current and former prisoners reported that inmates were forced to share a single water and toilet facility with CARDINAL cellmates , creating serious sanitation problems . Contagious diseases , particularly scabies , were widespread , and prisoners did not have access to adequate medical care . Additional discriminatory and arbitrary measures such as restrictions on family visits worsened the conditions of detention , particularly when prisoners sought redress for grievances about treatment and conditions .

On DATE , the government closed the " QUANTITY Avril " prison in GPE and moved prisoners to a new facility at ORG , a suburb of GPE . The capacity of the new prison was reportedly CARDINAL prisoners and designed to remedy serious problems of overcrowding in the CARDINAL Avril prison . Prisoners had previously complained of very poor conditions in TIME , including overcrowding , sanitation problems , and limited access to medical care .

A DATE PERSON report on the country ’s prisons entitled " The Walls of Silence " estimated that there were CARDINAL prisoners in CARDINAL prisons and CARDINAL juvenile detention centers . The report described a number of abuses , alleging that torture and humiliating treatment of prisoners were widespread .

In an DATE report , ORG ( HRW ) described the government practice of holding political prisoners in prolonged solitary confinement . During a press conference held in GPE in DATE , ORG announced that the government promised not to place prisoners in solitary confinement for DATE , the maximum time allowed for punishment according to the law . Shortly thereafter , the government confirmed that it had eliminated long - term solitary confinement . However , ORG reported that the government continued to keep some political prisoners , most of whom were outlawed NORP party An - Nahdha leaders , in small - group isolation .
According to prisoner and detainee testimony , prison conditions for women were generally better than those for men . Conditions for detainees and convicts were reportedly the same .

International and local NGOs reported that political prisoners regularly were moved among jails throughout the country , thereby making it more difficult for their families to deliver food to them and to discourage their supporters or the press from inquiring about them ( see section CARDINAL.b . ) . The ORG reported that other inmates were instructed to stay away from political prisoners and were punished severely for making contact with them .

In DATE the government reportedly approved access for ORG to make prison visits . Following this verbal agreement , however , ORG submitted a formal request for prison access , but despite multiple communications from ORG , by DATE end the government had not responded to ORG ’s request . In DATE the ICRC began conducting prison and detention center visits , following DATE of negotiations with the government . ORG ( ICRC ) reported that prison authorities had respected their mission and allowed them to conduct visits without obstacle . According to ORG the government began to put measures in place to improve conditions , including improved hygienic conditions and access to medical care . In DATE the ICRC submitted its first intermediary report to the government . The government did not permit media to inspect or monitor prison conditions .
ORG
Judges and the government exercised their authority to release prisoners or suspend their sentences , often on conditional parole ( see section CARDINAL.e . ) .

On DATE , President PERSON released CARDINAL prisoners from prison and granted " conditional freedom " to CARDINAL others . Among those released were CARDINAL members of the banned NORP party NORP , including PERSON , the former editor of ORG now defunct newspaper ORG , as well as other NORP . Also among those released were CARDINAL detainees , known as the ORG group , who had been arrested in DATE for allegedly preparing to commit terrorist attacks . International and domestic human rights NGOs , who have long called for the release of political prisoners , had been particularly vocal about PERSON and the PERSON group . After release PERSON and members of the ORG group complained of subsequent government harassment and excessive restrictions on personal movement due to their administrative control status ( see section CARDINAL.d . ) .

On DATE , President PERSON released an unannounced number of prisoners in advance of the DATE national holiday commemorating the President ’s accession to power in DATE . DATE reported on its Web site that CARDINAL of its former members that had been imprisoned in DATE were among those released . Several of those released had been sentenced to life in prison . ...
Political Prisoners and Detainees

The government denied that it held any political prisoners , and there was no definitive information regarding the number , if any , of such prisoners . Human rights organizations alleged that the government had arrested and imprisoned CARDINAL persons since DATE on charges related to a DATE antiterrorism law , without sufficient evidence that they had committed or planned to commit terrorist acts . Human rights activists and lawyers alleged that many of these detainees were tortured in ORG facilities and were forced to sign confessions .

ORG ( AISPP ) claimed that CARDINAL political prisoners remained from the caseload of NORP arrested in DATE and DATE . Very few of the prisoners were convicted for acts of violence . Most of those who were identified by international human rights groups as political prisoners or prisoners of conscience were arrested for violating laws that prohibit membership in illegal organizations and spreading false information aimed at undermining public order . Many were arrested for disseminating information produced by organizations such as CARDINAL . Former political prisoners stated their identity papers were marked in a way that resulted in their receiving harsher treatment . ... ”
CARDINAL . A report of DATE by ORG , on GPE , stated as to “ Background on Political Prisoners in GPE ” :

“ Government officials have stated repeatedly over DATE , and in response to the release of ORG report , GPE : ORG , that the country holds no political prisoners or “ prisoners of opinion , ” only criminals tried and convicted for violating NORP law . ORG disputes this characterization on CARDINAL basic grounds : first , that very few of the individuals in question were convicted of involvement in acts of violence ; and , second , that they were convicted in trials where their rights to a fair hearing were violated massively .

The vast majority of inmates who are commonly labeled as political prisoners were convicted for alleged connections to the opposition NORP party . CARDINAL was established in DATE as the successor to GPE ’s ORG ) , which was founded in DATE but never obtained legal recognition . CARDINAL also was denied legal recognition , although the government of President PERSON tolerated it until DATE , despite a law prohibiting political parties based on religion . In the DATE legislative elections , CARDINAL established itself as the leading opposition movement when its members , prevented by authorities from running on a party ticket , ran as independents and captured PERCENT of the vote .

DATE were marked by scattered violence linked to NORP , and the start of an arrest campaign against NORP members . ORG supporters were involved in numerous demonstrations on university campuses that turned violent . In DATE , party supporters were implicated in a fatal arson attack on a branch office of the ruling party in GPE , an incident that authorities presented as proof of the party ’s violent intentions . The NORP leadership denied authorizing the operation , although they termed it an understandable response to state repression . CARDINAL men were sentenced to death for their role in the attack and executed .

After DATE of arrests among the NORP ranks , the government announced in DATE the discovery of a plot by the party to assassinate the president by firing a Stinger missile at his plane and overthrow the government . They charged CARDINAL NORP leaders and backers , many of whom had already been in jail for DATE , of plotting the coup . CARDINAL suspected members of CARDINAL were arrested since the round - ups began in DATE , ORG reported in DATE . Torture of these suspects during interrogation was pervasive , according to both ORG and ORG .

In DATE , the CARDINAL alleged coup - plotters were judged in mass trials before CARDINAL military courts in GPE . The defendants retracted their confessions , saying they had been tortured . CARDINAL were convicted and CARDINAL acquitted in proceedings that human rights monitors denounced as unfair . CARDINAL of the defendants received life terms , although many of these were later commuted to DATE in prison . The verdicts were not subject to appeal and were all confirmed by ORG . These defendants comprise DATE of CARDINAL political prisoners being held DATE in GPE .

The government claimed then , and continues to claim , that an - Nahdha is an extremist group , willing to use violence to install a repressive theocracy . CARDINAL ’s leadership - in - exile says it routinely condemns violence and is committed to using only democratic and non - violent means to achieving a democratic and tolerant NORP state . It categorically denies the existence of the coup plot for which its leaders were convicted in DATE .

Since DATE , GPE has been largely free of political violence . The only fatal attack attributed to NORP was the DATE truck bomb that targeted a synagogue in ORG , killing CARDINAL . The suicide bomber was NORP . ORG claimed responsibility for the attack ; the NORP party , along with other NORP political parties , condemned it ; and no evidence has been disclosed linking the attack to CARDINAL .

NORP leaders say the absence of political violence in GPE reflects their movement ’s commitment to non - violence despite the harsh repression it has suffered . NORP authorities credit their own vigilance for DATE of quiet . In DATE since they imprisoned or drove into exile nearly the entire NORP leadership , authorities have jailed CARDINAL of suspected members of the party and of other lesser - known NORP groups . Their trials generally did not meet international norms for a fair trial . The charges often related not to specific acts of violence but rather to activities such as membership in an “ illegal ” organization , or collecting funds , attending meetings , or performing unspecified activities on behalf of an “ illegal ” organization . Others were convicted of graver charges , such as participation in a “ criminal gang ... established to prepare or carry out attacks on persons or property . ” Still others , notably those who had returned after living abroad , were tried in military courts , even though they were civilians , as permitted by the code of military justice , for the offense of serving " a terrorist organization that operates abroad " ( LAW Convictions by military courts are not subject to appeal . ”
CARDINAL . In their report of DATE , published on DATE , ORG stated , inter alia , the following as to GPE :

“ The government uses the threat of terrorism and religious extremism as a pretext to crack down on peaceful dissent . There are continuous and credible reports of torture and ill - treatment being used to obtain statements from suspects in custody . Sentenced prisoners also face deliberate ill - treatment .

In DATE ] President PERSON pardoned or conditionally released CARDINAL prisoners , including CARDINAL members of the banned NORP party NORP . In DATE the president pardoned or conditionally released CARDINAL more political prisoners , most of them CARDINAL members . Some were party leaders who had been imprisoned since their mass trial in DATE on dubious charges of plotting to topple the state . However , the number of political prisoners remained CARDINAL , as authorities arrested scores of young men in sweeps around the country and charged them under the DATE anti - terror law . Authorities made life difficult for released political prisoners , monitoring them closely , denying them passports and most jobs , and threatening to re - arrest some who spoke out on human rights or politics . ”
CARDINAL . The DATE report for DATE by ORG on GPE stated , inter alia :

“ Freedom of expression and association remained severely restricted . CARDINAL people were sentenced to lengthy prison terms following unfair trials on terrorism - related charges , while around CARDINAL others were still on trial at DATE . Torture and ill - treatment continued to be reported . CARDINAL of political prisoners sentenced after unfair trials in DATE , including prisoners of conscience , remained in prison . Many had been held for DATE and were reported to be in poor health . ...

CARDINAL political prisoners were released conditionally , CARDINAL of them in DATE ] and the rest in DATE , following presidential amnesties . Most had been imprisoned for over DATE because of their membership of the banned NORP organization , ORG ( ORG ) , after unfair trials before the ORG and PERSON military courts in DATE . CARDINAL other members of ORG remained imprisoned , some reportedly in poor health as a result of harsh prison conditions and torture in pre - trial detention DATE . Some were in urgent need of medical treatment . ... ”
